document.docAuthor: Eberhardt, Ursula, Beker, Henry J., Borgen, Torbjorn, Knudsen, Henning, Schuetz, Nicole & Elborne, Steen A.
document.masterDocTitle: A survey of Hebeloma (Hymenogastraceae) in Greenland

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A survey of Hebeloma (Hymenogastraceae) in Greenland

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Staatliches Museum fuer Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, D- 70191 Stuttgart, Germany
Rue Pere de Deken 19, B- 1040 Bruxelles, Belgium & Royal Holloway College, University of London, Egham, UK & Plantentuin Meise, Nieuwelaan 38, B- 1860 Meise, Belgium
Staatliches Museum fuer Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, D- 70191 Stuttgart, Germany

figureCitation.captionText: Figure 31. Hebeloma hiemale A SAE- 2018.225, photograph S. A. Elborne B distribution of cited collections C spores x 1600 and D cheilocystidia x 1000 of SAE- 2018.225 in Melzer's reagent. Scale bars: 5 µm; microphotographs H. K. J. Beker.

subSubSection.paragraph: Cap 1.1-8.0 cm in diameter, convex to umbonate, often broadly, margin smooth, sometimes involute, undulate in older specimens, tacky when moist, occasionally spotted, rarely hygrophanous, almost uniformly colored or variably bicolored, at center warm buff to grayish buff or dark pinkish buff through honey or ochraceous and dark olive buff to umber and clay pink or orange brown, at margin pale cream to cream to honey or pale pinkish buff, without any traces of veil. Lamellae when young very pale but becoming darker with maturity, emarginate to adnate, maximum depth 3-7 mm, number of lamellae {L} 35-71, droplets usually visible with naked eye or x 10 lens, occasionally absent, white fimbriate edge present. Stem (1.3-)1.5-10.75(-12) x (0.3-)0.35-1.2 {median} x (0.3-)0.55-1.4(-1.5) {base} cm, stem Q 2.5-17.2(-17.4), whitish to pale brownish at middle, hardly discoloring, gradually sordid brown in the mid portion, cylindrical to clavate, rarely subbulbous, usually pruinose particularly at apex, rarely with mycelial chords. Context firm, stem interior stuffed, becoming hollow with age and often with a superior wick, flesh often discoloring from base, particularly after handling. Smell raphanoid, sometimes with hints of cocoa, rarely absent. Taste mild to weakly bitter. Spore color dark olive buff or grayish brown through brownish olive to umber.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 31.
Hebeloma hiemale
A SAE-2018.225, photograph S.A. Elborne B distribution of cited collections C spores x 1600 and D cheilocystidia x 1000 of SAE-2018.225 in Melzer's reagent. Scale bars: 5 µm ; microphotographs H.K.J. Beker.

subSubSection.paragraph: Spores amygdaloid, limoniform, variably papillate, on ave. 10.0-12.5 x 5.0-7.5 µm , ave. Q = 1.6-2.1, yellow to yellow brown, usually guttulate, weakly, occasionally distinctly ornamented ((O1) O2 (O3)), perispore not or somewhat loosening (P0P1 (P2)), indistinctly to weakly dextrinoid ((D0) D1D2). Basidia 23-39(-43) x 7-10 µm , ave. Q = 3.2-4.3, mostly four-spored, often stipitate. Cheilocystidia usually clavate-lageniform, but occasionally slenderly clavate, clavate-stipitate, cylindrical or ventricose, rarely spathulate-lageniform or tapering, occasionally characteristically with apical or median wall thickening, sometimes geniculate or septate, rarely sinuate or rostrate, on ave. 40-65 x 5.5-9 (apex) x 3.5-5 (middle) x 4.5-7.5 (base) µm , ratios A/M = 1.46-2.48, A/B = 0.97-1.8, B/M = 1.26-1.77. Epicutis an ixocutis, 60-200 µm thick (measured from exsiccata), maximum hyphae width 4-6 µm , sometimes encrusted, trama elements beneath subcutis cylindrical, ellipsoidal, sausage-shaped up to 17 µm wide. Caulocystidia similar to cheilocystidia, up to 75 µm long, often septate, septa sometimes clamped, many cylindrical.

Salix glauca
in copse. Jameson Land, Nerlerit Inaat/Constable Pynt, Primulaelv, 70.74°N , 22.67°W , 7 Aug 2017, T. Borgen (TB17C.072, C-F-106776), 180 m, with
Bistorta vivipara
in heathland.

One of the five most commonly recorded
Hebeloma
species in Greenland, with 11.6% of the records. Common and widespread in Europe; also recorded from other parts of North America (https://mycoportal.org/portal/collections/list.php, accessed 2 Dec 2020). To our knowledge not recorded from alpine sites in Europe ( Beker et al. 2016 ).

Forty-four collections, mainly with
Salix glauca
(15),
Dryas
(10) and
S. herbacea
(6). Minor hosts are
S. arctophila
and
S. arctica
, and two collections were difficult to separate from the roots of
Bistorta vivipara
. Found in all types of habitats from scrubland, grassland and heathland to snowbeds. In the Rocky Mountains, the hosts are
S. arctica
,
S. glauca
,
S. planifolia
,
S. reticulata
,
Betula nana
and
Dryas
( Cripps et al. 2019 ). For lowland Europe, there is a long list of deciduous trees as probable hosts ( Beker et al. 2016 ).

subSubSection.type: hebeloma sect. velutipes vesterh.; ann. micol. a. g. m. t. 1: 60, 2004
subSubSection.paragraph:
Hebeloma
sect.
Velutipes Vesterh.
; Ann. Micol. A. G. M. T. 1: 60, 2004.
Stem velute, usually pruinose at least at apex, bulbous. Cheilocystidia gently clavate towards the apex, occasionally ventricose, spores rather strongly to very strongly dextrinoid.
